packetJourney.title: Packet Journey
packetJourney.description: Trace how a packet moves from a device through the router to the internet and back.
packetJourney.selectDevice: Select a device to trace its packet journey
packetJourney.noFlow: No active flow data for this device

idle.link: Ready to trace using MAC addresses
idle.network: Ready to trace using IP addresses
idle.application: Ready to trace at the application layer

deviceToRouter.link: Frame sent from device MAC to router MAC
deviceToRouter.network: Packet carries device source IP to server destination IP
deviceToRouter.transport: Client sends from an ephemeral port to the server port (e.g., 443)

routerProcessing.link: Router receives frame, strips link header, reads IP destination
routerProcessing.network: NAT rewrites the private source IP to the router’s public IP
routerProcessing.transport: Router tracks the connection for return traffic mapping
routerProcessing.application: Firewall rules may inspect application headers

routerToInternet.link: Frame sent from router WAN MAC to ISP gateway MAC
routerToInternet.network: Packet routes across the internet with the router’s public IP
routerToInternet.transport: Port mapping is stored for the return path

internetResponse.link: Response arrives at the router’s WAN interface from the ISP
internetResponse.network: Response targets the router’s public IP; the port identifies the flow
internetResponse.transport: Server responds on the established port pair
internetResponse.application: Server sends response data (HTML, JSON, file)

routerBack.link: Router rewrites destination MAC to the device MAC
routerBack.network: NAT reverses the mapping back to the device’s private IP
routerBack.transport: Original source port delivers to the correct application

complete.link: Journey complete. The device received the response via link‑layer delivery.
complete.network: Journey complete. The private IP communicated through the router’s public IP.
complete.transport: Journey complete. The full request/response cycle completed through ports.
complete.application: Journey complete. The application received the server response.

legend.flowInfoBody: These flows are examples of active traffic, not open services.

privateIp.question: Which of these is a private IP address?
privateIp.explanation: 192.168.x.x is a private range used inside local networks. 8.8.8.8 is Google's public DNS. 203.0.113.12 is an example public IP address.
privateIp.why: Private ranges indicate local devices; public IPs identify systems on the internet.
privateIp.nextStep: Treat 192.168.x.x, 10.x.x.x, and 172.16–31.x.x as internal; the router’s WAN IP is the public address.

macPurpose.question: What is a MAC address (Local ID) used for?
answers: Routing packets across the internet
Identifying devices on the local network
Encrypting your data
macPurpose.explanation: MAC addresses are hardware identifiers used for delivery on a local link. Routers replace link‑layer headers when forwarding traffic to the internet.
macPurpose.why: MACs identify devices on a local segment, not across the internet.
macPurpose.nextStep: Use the router’s device list to map MAC addresses to physical devices.

guestNetwork.question: Why would you put guests on a separate network?
answers: To give them faster internet speed
To prevent them from accessing your personal devices
Because there's a limit to devices on one network
guestNetwork.explanation: A guest network isolates visitors from your main LAN. Guests can reach the internet but not your personal devices.
guestNetwork.why: Isolation limits what a compromised guest device can access.
guestNetwork.nextStep: Enable a guest SSID and keep it firewalled from the main network.

unknownDevice.question: You notice an unknown device on your network. What should you do?
answers: Ignore it - it's probably fine
Investigate and possibly block it
Unplug your router immediately
unknownDevice.explanation: Unknown devices may be inventory gaps or unauthorized access. Use the router’s client list to identify the device by MAC/vendor and remove it if unrecognized.
unknownDevice.why: Unidentified devices can indicate misuse or intrusion.
unknownDevice.nextStep: Verify the device, then block it or rotate the Wi‑Fi password.

iotIsolation.question: Why are IoT devices (cameras, thermostats) often put on a separate network?
answers: They need special internet settings
They're often insecure and could be used to attack other devices
They use too much bandwidth
iotIsolation.explanation: Many IoT devices ship with weak security and infrequent updates. Isolation prevents a compromised device from reaching personal computers.
iotIsolation.why: IoT devices are common entry points; segmentation limits lateral movement.
iotIsolation.nextStep: Place IoT devices on a separate VLAN or SSID with restricted access.

tenNetwork.question: What type of IP address range is 10.0.x.x?
answers: Public IP range
Private IP range for internal networks
Reserved for government use
tenNetwork.explanation: 10.0.0.0/8 is one of the RFC1918 private ranges, along with 172.16.0.0/12 and 192.168.0.0/16. These addresses are not routed on the public internet.
tenNetwork.why: Recognizing private ranges prevents you from assuming a device is publicly reachable.
tenNetwork.nextStep: Treat 10.x addresses as internal and check the router for the public IP.

wpa3.question: Why does the staff network use WPA3 while guest uses WPA2?
answers: WPA3 is slower, only staff can handle it
WPA3 provides stronger encryption for sensitive data
There's no meaningful difference
wpa3.explanation: WPA3 strengthens protection against offline password guessing and uses modern key exchange. Staff traffic should use the strongest available option.
wpa3.why: Stronger Wi‑Fi encryption reduces the risk of credential exposure.
wpa3.nextStep: Use WPA3 when available and keep WPA2 only for legacy devices.

printerRisk.question: Why is the printer flagged as a security risk?
answers: Printers can't be secure
It still has the default password, making it easy to hack
It's connected to the wrong network
printerRisk.explanation: The printer still has default credentials. That allows unauthorized access to print jobs and can provide a foothold in the network.
printerRisk.why: Default credentials are a common entry point for attackers.
printerRisk.nextStep: Change the printer password and keep it on a restricted network.

corpIsolation.question: Why can't customers on guest Wi-Fi access the file server?
answers: The file server is turned off
Guest network is isolated from corporate network
Customers don't have the password
corpIsolation.explanation: Guest and corporate networks are separated by firewall rules. Guests can reach the internet but not internal servers.
corpIsolation.why: Segmentation protects internal data even if guest Wi-Fi is compromised.
corpIsolation.nextStep: Verify guest Wi-Fi cannot reach internal servers or printers.

openWifi.question: What does 'Open' network security mean?
answers: Anyone can join without a password
The network has no firewall
The Wi-Fi signal is publicly visible
openWifi.explanation: An open network has no link‑layer encryption. Anyone on the same Wi‑Fi can observe or modify traffic.
openWifi.why: Open Wi‑Fi increases the risk of interception.
openWifi.nextStep: Avoid sensitive logins on open Wi-Fi or use a VPN.

evilTwin.question: What is an 'evil twin' attack?
answers: When someone clones your device
A fake Wi-Fi network that mimics a legitimate one
When two routers interfere with each other
evilTwin.explanation: An attacker creates a rogue access point that mimics a legitimate SSID to capture traffic or credentials.
evilTwin.why: Look‑alike SSIDs can intercept traffic and steal logins.
evilTwin.nextStep: Verify the official SSID with staff and turn off auto-join for public Wi-Fi.

publicPrivateIp.question: On public Wi-Fi, why might your IP still be private (e.g., 172.16.x.x)?
answers: Because the hotspot uses NAT and private addressing
Because public Wi-Fi always gives out public IPs
Because private IPs are only for home networks
publicPrivateIp.explanation: Public hotspots often use private addressing with NAT. Your device gets a private IP; the hotspot shares one public IP.
publicPrivateIp.why: Private IPs can exist in public places too; NAT hides many devices behind one public IP.
publicPrivateIp.nextStep: Look for the NAT boundary: your device has a private IP and the hotspot has the public IP.

httpsImportance.question: On public Wi-Fi, why is HTTPS especially important?
answers: HTTPS makes websites load faster
HTTPS encrypts your data so others on the network can't read it
HTTPS prevents viruses
httpsImportance.explanation: HTTPS encrypts the HTTP session between your browser and the server using TLS. Interceptors can see metadata but not the content.
httpsImportance.why: HTTPS protects credentials and content on untrusted networks.
httpsImportance.nextStep: Check for HTTPS (lock icon) before entering passwords or personal data.

vpn.question: What does a VPN do on public Wi-Fi?
answers: Makes your internet faster
Creates an encrypted tunnel for all your traffic
Blocks other users from connecting
vpn.explanation: A VPN encrypts and authenticates all traffic between your device and a VPN gateway, not just browser traffic.
vpn.why: A VPN protects multiple apps on untrusted networks.
vpn.nextStep: Use a reputable VPN when working or banking on public Wi-Fi.

safeBehavior.question: What should you avoid doing on public Wi-Fi?
answers: Browsing news websites
Logging into your bank without a VPN
Checking the weather
safeBehavior.explanation: Avoid financial or account actions on public Wi‑Fi without a VPN. Even HTTPS cannot prevent all attacks on compromised networks.
safeBehavior.why: High‑value actions carry higher risk on public networks.
safeBehavior.nextStep: Delay banking and password changes until you are on a trusted network.

actions.title: Actions
actions.debriefIntro: Here's what you did and why it matters.
actions.startHereBody: Complete these actions to secure the scenario.

blockUnknown.title: Block the unknown device
blockUnknown.instruction: Select the "Generic Smart Controller" and block it.
blockUnknown.success: Unknown device blocked. Immediate risk reduced.
blockUnknown.failure: That device is not the unknown device. Identify the unfamiliar one first.
blockUnknown.tip: Verify unknown devices and block those you cannot identify.

changeCameraPassword.title: Change the camera password
changeCameraPassword.instruction: Find the Indoor Camera and change its default password.
changeCameraPassword.success: Default password changed. A common IoT entry point is removed.
changeCameraPassword.failure: Select the Indoor Camera that still has a default password.
changeCameraPassword.tip: Default credentials are a common compromise vector.

enableGuest.title: Enable the guest network
enableGuest.instruction: Confirm the guest network is enabled for visitors.
enableGuest.success: Guest access is separated from your personal devices.
enableGuest.failure: Select a device on the guest network to confirm it's enabled.
enableGuest.tip: Guest networks keep visitors from reaching your main devices.

enableGuest.title: Separate customer Wi-Fi
enableGuest.instruction: Confirm the guest network is enabled for customers.
enableGuest.success: Customers are isolated from internal systems.
enableGuest.failure: Select a device on the guest network to confirm it's enabled.
enableGuest.tip: Guest networks protect internal resources from visitors.

isolatePrinter.title: Isolate the printer
isolatePrinter.instruction: Select the office printer and isolate it from staff devices.
isolatePrinter.success: Printer isolated from staff devices, reducing exposure.
isolatePrinter.failure: Select the office printer before isolating it.
isolatePrinter.tip: Printers often have weak security and should be segmented.

blockUnknown.title: Block the unregistered device
blockUnknown.instruction: Identify the unregistered device and remove it from the network.
blockUnknown.success: The unknown device is blocked and no longer a threat.
blockUnknown.failure: Select the unregistered device before blocking it.
blockUnknown.tip: Unregistered corporate devices should be removed immediately.

verifySsid.title: Verify the official Wi-Fi
verifySsid.instruction: Select the official hotel access point.
verifySsid.success: You identified the official access point.
verifySsid.failure: That is not the official hotel access point.
verifySsid.tip: Attackers often create look‑alike SSIDs to trick guests.

blockFakeAp.title: Report the fake access point
blockFakeAp.instruction: Identify the suspicious Wi-Fi device and flag it.
blockFakeAp.success: The fake access point is flagged and avoided.
blockFakeAp.failure: Select the suspicious access point before reporting it.
blockFakeAp.tip: Avoid suspicious SSIDs and alert staff.

onboarding.mapOnlyNotice: Map view is locked during the tour.

welcome_hook.title: Your Network is Always Talking
welcome_hook.content: Devices on your network exchange traffic continuously—phones, TVs, and thermostats. This course shows who they talk to and what is exposed.

welcome_challenge.title: The Hidden Risks
welcome_challenge.content: Attackers exploit forgotten devices, weak passwords, and unencrypted connections. Security starts with visibility.

welcome_mission.title: Your Network Discovery Mission
welcome_mission.content: You will learn to read the network layer by layer, identify risks, and take corrective actions.

map_solar_system.title: Your Network as a Solar System
map_solar_system.content: The map uses a solar‑system layout: the router at the center, rings for trust zones, and dots for devices.

map_trust_zones.title: Understanding Trust Zones
map_trust_zones.content: Networks are segmented into zones: main, guest, and IoT. Isolation limits what a compromised device can reach.

map_device_indicators.title: Reading Device Signals
map_device_indicators.content: Pulsing rings mark risk flags such as unknown device, default password, or outdated firmware.

scenario_contexts.title: Real-World Network Scenarios
scenario_contexts.content: Scenarios reflect common environments: home networks, small offices, and hotel Wi‑Fi. Each has different risks and controls.

scenario_select.title: Choose Your Environment
scenario_select.content: Select a scenario. You can switch anytime to compare how risks and controls differ.

layers_why.title: Seeing in Layers
layers_why.content: Network layers expose different identifiers and controls. Switching layers lets you trace traffic from link to application.

layers_link.title: Link Layer: Physical Identity
layers_link.content: The Link layer shows MAC addresses and local delivery. It is where you spot unauthorized devices.

layers_network.title: Network Layer: Logical Addresses
layers_network.content: The Network layer shows IP addressing and routing. It distinguishes local private IPs from internet‑facing addresses.

layers_transport.title: Transport Layer: Connections & Ports
layers_transport.content: The Transport layer shows active connections, port numbers, and whether a flow uses TCP or UDP.

layers_application.title: Application Layer: What's Being Communicated
layers_application.content: The Application layer shows protocols and encryption status. HTTPS uses TLS; HTTP is unencrypted.

device_inspection.title: Investigating Devices
device_inspection.content: Select a device to view its identity, active flows, and risk flags. Prioritize high‑risk flags.

device_risk_flags.title: Understanding Risk Flags
device_risk_flags.content: Risk flags indicate concrete issues such as default passwords, outdated firmware, or unknown devices.

device_learn_tab.title: Built-in Learning
device_learn_tab.content: Use the Learn tab for device‑specific risks and mitigations.

quiz_intro.title: Test Your Understanding
quiz_intro.content: Short checks reinforce key concepts. Use them to confirm understanding.

mission_complete.title: Mission Complete
mission_complete.content: You can now map devices, interpret layers, and act on risks. Continue with scenarios to build fluency.
